title: üìñ The Acceptance of Islam
subtitle: When Wealth and Nobility Bowed to Allah

sections.heading: A Noble Merchant in Makkah
paragraphs: Hazrat Uthman ibn Affan (RA) was among the wealthiest and most respected men in Makkah. A successful merchant, he was admired for his honesty, kindness, and gentle character. Though he lived among idol worshippers, Uthman (RA) never bowed to idols, drank alcohol, or took part in immoral practices. Even before Islam, he was known as pure and modest.

sections.heading: Abu Bakr‚Äôs Invitation
paragraphs: When the Prophet Muhammad Ô∑∫ began calling people to Islam, Abu Bakr as-Siddiq (RA), his closest companion, worked tirelessly to invite others. Abu Bakr (RA) approached Uthman (RA), knowing his good heart, and explained the message of Islam:
Worship only Allah, the Creator.
Leave the false gods and idols.
Follow Muhammad Ô∑∫, the Messenger of Allah.
Uthman (RA) listened with an open heart. The message of tawheed (oneness of Allah) resonated deeply with him. Without hesitation, he went to the Prophet Ô∑∫, heard his words, and declared:
‚ÄúI bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His Messenger.‚Äù
With this, Uthman (RA) became one of the earliest Muslims.

sections.heading: Facing Opposition
paragraphs: His conversion enraged his clan, the powerful Banu Umayyah. His uncle Al-Hakam ibn Abi al-As tried to pressure and even imprison him, demanding he abandon Islam. But Uthman (RA) refused to leave the truth.
The Prophet Ô∑∫ reassured him with glad tidings of Paradise and praised his patience. Uthman (RA) stood firm, choosing faith over family, wealth, and status.

sections.heading: Marriage to Ruqayyah (RA)
paragraphs: Shortly after accepting Islam, Uthman (RA) was blessed with another honor ‚Äî he married Ruqayyah (RA), the daughter of the Prophet Ô∑∫. This bond brought him even closer to the Messenger Ô∑∫, and his home became a household of faith and devotion.

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: Faith Above Status: Uthman (RA) left behind the approval of his noble family to stand with the truth.
The Power of Da‚Äôwah: Abu Bakr (RA)‚Äôs sincerity in inviting others led to the conversion of one of the greatest companions.
Strength in Patience: Despite pressure and persecution, Uthman (RA) never wavered in his new faith.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: Uthman ibn Affan (RA) would go on to become one of the greatest pillars of Islam. His early acceptance showed that even the wealthy and noble could humble themselves before Allah, and his example inspired others to follow.

title: üìñ Dhul-Nurayn ‚Äì The Possessor of Two Lights
subtitle: The Man Who Married Two Daughters of the Prophet Ô∑∫

sections.heading: A Rare Honor
paragraphs: Hazrat Uthman ibn Affan (RA) is remembered in history by a title no other man has ever received: Dhul-Nurayn (The Possessor of Two Lights). This was because he married two daughters of the Prophet Muhammad Ô∑∫ ‚Äî Ruqayyah (RA) and later Umm Kulthum (RA) ‚Äî one after the other.
The Prophet Ô∑∫ once said:
‚ÄúIf I had a third daughter, I would have married her to Uthman.‚Äù
This was a testimony to Uthman‚Äôs character, modesty, and piety.

sections.heading: His First Marriage: Ruqayyah (RA)
paragraphs: Not long after Uthman (RA) accepted Islam, he married Ruqayyah (RA), the daughter of the Prophet Ô∑∫. Their marriage was full of love and faith.
When Muslims migrated to Abyssinia to escape persecution in Makkah, Uthman (RA) and Ruqayyah (RA) were among them. It was during this migration that the Prophet Ô∑∫ said:
‚ÄúUthman is the first man to migrate with his family in the way of Allah after Lut (Lot).‚Äù

Later, they returned to Madinah, and Uthman (RA) continued to stand by Ruqayyah (RA) during difficult times. During the Battle of Badr, she fell gravely ill. Uthman (RA) stayed behind to care for her with the Prophet‚Äôs permission. She passed away during the battle, and Uthman (RA) was heartbroken.

sections.heading: His Second Marriage: Umm Kulthum (RA)
paragraphs: After some time, the Prophet Ô∑∫ married his second daughter, Umm Kulthum (RA), to Uthman (RA). This second marriage earned him the title Dhul-Nurayn. No other man in history was honored by marrying two daughters of a Prophet.

The couple lived together in harmony, and Uthman (RA) continued his life of faith, modesty, and service to Islam. When Umm Kulthum (RA) too passed away, the Prophet Ô∑∫ was deeply saddened. He said with love:
‚ÄúIf I had a third daughter, I would have given her to Uthman.‚Äù

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: Marriage in Faith: The Prophet Ô∑∫ trusted Uthman (RA) with his daughters, showing his deep respect for his character.
Patience in Loss: Uthman (RA) endured the pain of losing two wives, yet remained steadfast in faith.
A Title of Honor: Dhul-Nurayn remains one of the most unique titles in Islamic history, symbolizing Uthman‚Äôs closeness to the Prophet Ô∑∫.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: Hazrat Uthman (RA) is remembered not only as a Caliph but as the man of two lights, honored in a way no other man was. His marriages reflect the trust, love, and respect the Prophet Ô∑∫ had for him. It also shows that wealth and nobility meant little compared to faith, modesty, and sincerity.

title: üìñ The Well of Rumah
subtitle: The Water that Flowed Because of Uthman (RA)

sections.heading: Water Scarcity in Madinah
paragraphs: When the Muslims migrated to Madinah, fresh water was not easy to access. Most wells either belonged to specific tribes or had salty or bitter water that was difficult to drink.

There was one especially valuable source of clean water: the well of Rumah (also known as Bi‚Äôr Rumah). But this well did not belong to the Muslims. It was owned by a man from the local people, and he would sell water from it for a price.

sections.heading: Uthman‚Äôs Purchase
paragraphs: The situation was difficult for the poor Muslims, who could not always afford to buy water. The Prophet Muhammad Ô∑∫ said to the companions that whoever would buy the well and make it free for the Muslims would earn a place in Paradise.
Hazrat Uthman ibn Affan (RA) stepped forward. He approached the owner and offered to buy the well so that it could be used by everyone in Madinah without cost.

At first, the owner refused to sell the entire well. But Uthman (RA) negotiated and purchased half of it. This meant that on certain days, the water would be available for free to the Muslims. People came in large numbers on Uthman‚Äôs days, filling their containers generously until they had enough for days.
Eventually, seeing that the business was no longer profitable, the owner agreed to sell the rest of the well to Uthman (RA). Uthman (RA) then made it fully public property for the sake of Allah.

sections.heading: Charity for Everyone
paragraphs: From that point onward, water from the well of Rumah was free for every Muslim. The wealthy, the poor, the traveler, and the orphan ‚Äî all could drink without paying. Uthman (RA) never asked for anything in return.

This act of charity became one of the most famous examples of sadaqah jariyah (ongoing charity) in Islamic history ‚Äî a gift that benefits people continuously and keeps rewarding the giver even after death.

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: Selfless Charity: Uthman (RA) did not buy the well for profit or honor ‚Äî he bought it so that no believer would be denied water.
Sadaqah Jariyah: A single deed can continue to benefit people for generations and bring reward long after death.
Serving the Ummah: True leadership is when a person uses their wealth to relieve the hardship of others.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: The well of Rumah became known as a gift of Uthman (RA) to the Ummah. His purchase of that well is remembered as an act of love, generosity, and service ‚Äî a reminder that wealth spent for Allah never goes to waste.

title: üìñ The Army of Tabuk
subtitle: When Uthman (RA) Equipped the Army of Islam Alone

sections.heading: The Difficult Expedition
paragraphs: In the 9th year of Hijrah, the Prophet Muhammad Ô∑∫ called the Muslims to prepare for a great expedition ‚Äî the Battle of Tabuk. The Roman Empire was threatening from the north, and Muslims needed to defend themselves.

But it was summer, the hottest time of the year. The journey was long, food was scarce, and resources were low. The Muslims faced a severe shortage of provisions. This campaign became known as ‚ÄúJaysh al-‚ÄòUsrah‚Äù (The Army of Hardship).
The Prophet Ô∑∫ stood before the companions and urged them to donate whatever they could to support the army.

sections.heading: The Call for Donations
paragraphs: Some companions brought what little they had ‚Äî a few dates, a cloak, or a handful of food. Others brought their wealth in larger amounts. Abu Bakr (RA) brought everything he owned, Umar (RA) brought half his wealth, and other companions gave as much as they could.
Then came Uthman ibn Affan (RA).

sections.heading: Uthman‚Äôs Contribution
paragraphs: Uthman (RA) stepped forward and donated:
1,000 camels fully equipped with saddles and supplies.
70 horses for the soldiers.
1,000 dinars in gold poured into the Prophet‚Äôs lap.
The Prophet Ô∑∫ kept repeating:
‚ÄúNothing will harm Uthman after what he has done today.‚Äù (Tirmidhi)
This statement was both a recognition of Uthman‚Äôs immense sacrifice and a guarantee of Allah‚Äôs forgiveness.

sections.heading: The Reaction of the Companions
paragraphs: The companions were stunned by the scale of his donation. While others gave from what they had, Uthman (RA) gave in abundance until the army was fully equipped. What had been called ‚ÄúThe Army of Hardship‚Äù became an army ready for battle, largely due to his generosity.

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: Giving Without Limits: Uthman (RA) didn‚Äôt just give part of his wealth ‚Äî he gave until the need was completely fulfilled.
Faith in Sacrifice: He understood that wealth given for Allah is never lost.
A Source of Hope: The Prophet‚Äôs Ô∑∫ words, ‚ÄúNothing will harm Uthman after today,‚Äù remain a testament to the power of sincere generosity.
Leadership by Example: When people saw Uthman‚Äôs giving, it inspired them to give more, regardless of their means.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: The Army of Tabuk was a defining moment in Uthman‚Äôs (RA) life. It showed how one man‚Äôs wealth, when spent for Allah, can uplift an entire nation. His generosity became legendary, and his example continues to inspire Muslims to spend freely in the path of Allah.

title: üìñ The Prophet Ô∑∫ Testifying to Uthman‚Äôs Modesty
subtitle: The Man Before Whom Even Angels Felt Shy

sections.heading: Uthman‚Äôs Character
paragraphs: Hazrat Uthman ibn Affan (RA) was known among the companions for his extreme modesty (haya). He spoke softly, lowered his gaze, and was always careful not to make others uncomfortable. Despite being wealthy and influential, he lived simply and humbly.
His modesty was not only noticed by people ‚Äî but by the Prophet Ô∑∫ himself.

sections.heading: The Day with Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman
paragraphs: One day, the Prophet Muhammad Ô∑∫ was sitting at home with his legs uncovered, relaxing with Abu Bakr (RA) and Umar (RA). They entered freely, and the Prophet Ô∑∫ remained at ease in their presence.
Then Uthman ibn Affan (RA) knocked and entered. The Prophet Ô∑∫ immediately sat upright and adjusted his clothing, covering his legs.
The companions were surprised and asked him why he changed his posture only when Uthman (RA) came in.
The Prophet Ô∑∫ replied:
‚ÄúShall I not feel shy before a man before whom even the angels feel shy?‚Äù (Muslim, Tirmidhi)

sections.heading: The Depth of His Haya (Modesty)
paragraphs: This hadith shows that Uthman‚Äôs (RA) modesty was so pure and sincere that even the angels felt shy in his presence. His behavior was a reflection of his heart ‚Äî gentle, respectful, and God-conscious at every moment.

sections.heading: Examples of His Modesty
paragraphs: He rarely raised his voice, even in matters of leadership.
He would avoid bathing fully naked, even in privacy, out of shyness before Allah.
He lived simply, often fasting, praying, and reciting the Qur‚Äôan, avoiding excess in all things.

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: True Strength is Gentle: Modesty is not weakness but a form of spiritual strength.
Angelic Character: To have angels feel shy before you is a sign of purity of heart.
Respect for Privacy: Uthman (RA) teaches us to maintain dignity in all settings, public or private.
Balance in Leadership: Despite being Caliph, he ruled with gentleness, showing that power does not need harshness.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: Hazrat Uthman (RA) became a symbol of modesty in Islam. His character is remembered as one of purity and dignity, admired not only by people but also acknowledged by the Prophet Ô∑∫ and the angels themselves.

title: üìñ The Compilation of the Qur‚Äôan
subtitle: How Uthman (RA) Preserved the Qur‚Äôan for All Generations

sections.heading: Islam‚Äôs Expansion and a New Challenge
paragraphs: By the time of Hazrat Uthman‚Äôs (RA) caliphate, Islam had spread far beyond Arabia ‚Äî into Iraq, Persia, Syria, and Egypt. Muslims from different regions spoke different dialects of Arabic.
As Islam reached new lands, differences in recitation (qira‚Äôat) of the Qur‚Äôan began to appear. Some Muslims argued over pronunciations, leading to confusion and disputes.
When Hudhayfah ibn al-Yaman (RA), a companion of the Prophet Ô∑∫, witnessed Muslims in Iraq disagreeing about recitation, he rushed to Uthman (RA) with concern:
‚ÄúO Leader of the Believers! Save this Ummah before they differ about the Book like the Jews and Christians differed about their scriptures.‚Äù

sections.heading: Uthman‚Äôs Decision
paragraphs: Uthman (RA) realized the danger of division. He gathered the senior companions, including Zayd ibn Thabit (RA) ‚Äî who had previously compiled the Qur‚Äôan under Abu Bakr (RA).
He ordered:
"Copy the Qur‚Äôan in the dialect of Quraysh, for it was revealed in their tongue."
A committee was formed with Zayd ibn Thabit (RA), Abdullah ibn al-Zubayr (RA), Sa‚Äôid ibn al-‚ÄòAs (RA), and Abdur Rahman ibn Harith (RA).

sections.heading: The Official Mushaf
paragraphs: The committee carefully prepared a master copy of the Qur‚Äôan, ensuring accuracy by cross-verifying with memorized recitations and existing manuscripts.

When it was completed, Uthman (RA) had several official copies made and sent to major Islamic centers ‚Äî Makkah, Basra, Kufa, Damascus, and others. He ordered that all other personal manuscripts with differing dialects be withdrawn to avoid future disputes.
This was not destruction of the Qur‚Äôan, but rather preservation of its unity.

sections.heading: Unity Through the Qur‚Äôan
paragraphs: From that day, every copy of the Qur‚Äôan in the world traces back to the standardized Mushaf prepared under Uthman (RA). The Qur‚Äôan remains unchanged, word for word, letter for letter ‚Äî a living miracle.
The Prophet Ô∑∫ had promised:
‚ÄúAllah will protect this Book from corruption.‚Äù
And Uthman‚Äôs (RA) efforts were the means by which Allah fulfilled this promise.

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: Foresight in Leadership: Uthman (RA) acted before small differences could divide the Ummah.
Unity Through the Qur‚Äôan: His work preserved not just the text, but the unity of Muslims around the Book of Allah.
Accountability: As Caliph, he saw the preservation of faith as his greatest duty.
Sadaqah Jariyah: His act of standardizing the Qur‚Äôan continues to benefit Muslims until today.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: The compilation of the Qur‚Äôan under Hazrat Uthman (RA) stands as one of the greatest services to Islam. Because of his vision, Muslims around the world ‚Äî from Indonesia to Africa, from Arabia to Europe ‚Äî recite the same Qur‚Äôan without variation.
His legacy is that of a man who preserved Allah‚Äôs final revelation for all time.

title: üìñ His Patience in Caliphate
subtitle: When Uthman (RA) Faced Rebellion with Forbearance

sections.heading: The Golden Beginning
paragraphs: When Hazrat Uthman ibn Affan (RA) became the third Caliph after Umar (RA), the Ummah entered a time of prosperity. Trade flourished, wealth increased, and Islam spread into new lands. Uthman (RA) expanded the empire, built infrastructure, and strengthened the navy.
The first six years of his caliphate were peaceful and productive. But as the empire grew, new challenges arose.

sections.heading: Seeds of Rebellion
paragraphs: Faraway provinces had governors and officials, and not all of them ruled with fairness. Some people began to complain about leadership. Opportunists and hypocrites, especially influenced by Abdullah ibn Saba (a figure from Yemen who spread discord), began fueling unrest.
False rumors spread against Uthman (RA): accusations of nepotism, misuse of funds, and favoritism. None of these were true ‚Äî but they gained traction among people who had not known him personally.

sections.heading: Uthman‚Äôs Response
paragraphs: Despite the accusations, Uthman (RA) remained gentle and forbearing. Unlike Umar (RA), who was strict in governance, Uthman (RA) was soft-hearted. He avoided using harsh measures against rebels, hoping they would repent and return to reason.
He once said:
‚ÄúI do not wish to meet Allah with the blood of Muslims on my hands.‚Äù
When companions urged him to punish the rebels, he refused. His nature of modesty and patience guided him, even as the unrest grew.

sections.heading: Pressure and Siege
paragraphs: Eventually, rebels from Egypt and Kufa marched to Madinah. They besieged Uthman‚Äôs house, cutting him off from the mosque and the people.
The companions ‚Äî Ali (RA), Talha (RA), Zubair (RA), and others ‚Äî offered to defend him by force. But Uthman (RA) forbade them, saying:
‚ÄúI do not allow anyone to shed blood for my sake. This matter must not be settled by the sword among Muslims.‚Äù
Even as he was falsely accused and betrayed, Uthman (RA) held firm to patience.

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: Patience in Trials: True strength is not always in retaliation but in bearing hardships with faith.
Leadership with Mercy: Uthman (RA) chose peace and unity over conflict, even at personal cost.
Accountability Before Allah: He feared more about facing Allah with Muslim blood on his hands than about losing power.
A Test of Faith: His trial showed that even the most righteous leaders can face slander and opposition.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: Hazrat Uthman (RA) became a symbol of patience and forbearance. His calmness in the face of false accusations and rebellion showed his deep trust in Allah. Though he suffered betrayal in this world, his reward with Allah is eternal.

title: üìñ The Final Days and Martyrdom of Hazrat Uthman (RA)
subtitle: The Caliph Who Died with the Qur‚Äôan in His Hands

sections.heading: The Siege of His House
paragraphs: In the later years of his caliphate, rebels from Egypt, Kufa, and Basra spread false accusations against Uthman (RA) and eventually marched to Madinah. They surrounded his house, preventing him from leading prayers in the mosque.
The companions ‚Äî including Ali ibn Abi Talib (RA), Talha (RA), Zubair (RA), and even the youth like Hasan (RA) and Husayn (RA) ‚Äî offered to defend him with the sword.
But Uthman (RA) refused, saying:
‚ÄúI do not want a single drop of Muslim blood spilled for my sake. I will not be the first Caliph to cause bloodshed among the Ummah.‚Äù
His house remained under siege for days, with little food or water reaching him.

sections.heading: His Patience and Faith
paragraphs: Despite the suffering, Uthman (RA) remained calm and devoted. He continued fasting, praying, and reciting the Qur‚Äôan. He reminded those around him of the Prophet Ô∑∫‚Äôs words:
‚ÄúUthman, perhaps Allah will clothe you with a shirt (leadership), and if the hypocrites want you to remove it, do not remove it until you meet Me.‚Äù
He understood that this was his test, and he chose patience over resistance.

sections.heading: The Day of Martyrdom
paragraphs: On the 18th of Dhul-Hijjah, 35 AH, the rebels broke into his house. Uthman (RA), weakened from fasting, sat calmly with the Qur‚Äôan open in front of him.
His wife, Naila (RA), tried to protect him but was injured. The rebels struck Uthman (RA), and his blessed blood fell upon the page of the Qur‚Äôan at the verse:
‚ÄúSo Allah will suffice you against them. And He is the Hearing, the Knowing.‚Äù (Qur‚Äôan 2:137)
Thus, the Caliph of Islam, the modest and generous Dhul-Nurayn, met his Lord as a martyr, his last moments spent in the recitation of Allah‚Äôs Book.

sections.heading: Aftermath
paragraphs: His martyrdom shocked the Ummah. It was the first time a Caliph had been assassinated, and it marked the beginning of deep trials in the Muslim world. But his patience and refusal to shed Muslim blood left a lasting lesson: unity and peace were more important than power.

sections.heading: Lessons from the Story
paragraphs: Patience in the Face of Injustice: Uthman (RA) chose to endure harm rather than ignite civil war.
Closeness to Qur‚Äôan: He died reciting the Qur‚Äôan, showing his lifelong connection to Allah‚Äôs word.
Martyrdom of the Innocent: His death proved that even the most righteous may face betrayal, but their reward is with Allah.
Leadership as Trust: He carried the weight of leadership with humility until his final breath.

sections.heading: Legacy
paragraphs: Hazrat Uthman ibn Affan (RA) left behind a legacy of generosity, modesty, and patience. As Dhul-Nurayn, the husband of two daughters of the Prophet Ô∑∫, the compiler of the Qur‚Äôan, and the man of unmatched charity, his martyrdom became a seal of honor upon his life.
To this day, he is remembered as a leader who gave everything ‚Äî his wealth, his comfort, and finally his life ‚Äî for the sake of Islam.
